translated: Jātaka
The Collection of Eight
The Chapter on Kaccāna
The Jātaka of the Eight-Faced One
“This was formerly called the low-lying area,
with much mud and much water;
It was the dwelling of the king of cranes,
my ancestral home.
We used to live on frogs,
but we don’t abandon our territory.”
“Who would want to be a second
to the unprincipled Bandharā?
Who would make my children and grandchildren
safe and sound?”
“The whole earth is a swamp
as far as the ocean.
The elephant is exhausted, great king,
and the bull elephant finds no pleasure in the trunk.”
“Now that I’ve left here,
the king’s released me from the palace.
I’ll delight in myself,
living in the fork of a tree.”
“Now that I’ve left here,
the king’s released me from the palace.
I’ll drink the best water

original: yūthassa purato vajaṁ”.🔽“Taṁ maṁ kāmehi sammattaṁ,
analyzed: yūthassa puratas vaja  tam mama kāmehi sammatta
translated: and bellow in front of the herd.” 🔽“I was addicted to sensual pleasures,
attached to sensual pleasures, released by sensual pleasures.
The hunter Bharadvaja brought me here.
May you be fortunate, outsider.”
“In the pitch-black darkness
on a high mountain peak,
She said to me with gentle and soft words,
‘Don’t kick the dog.’

analyzed: a sa sayam jāti khayanta dassī
translated: “There is no doubt that I have seen the end of birth,
I will not enter a womb again.
This is my last birth, there will be no future lives for me,

analyzed: khīṇaḥ me sa sāraḥ punabbhavāya ati
translated: My wandering on is finished, there is no continuation of existence for me.”
The Birth Story of Aṭṭhasaddha, the Second.
